places.generalDescription: The National Mosque of Malaysia, located in Kuala Lumpur, is a must-visit architectural marvel spread across 13 acres. It can accommodate up to 15,000 worshippers and features a main prayer hall adorned with intricate Quranic verses. The mosque's main dome represents Malaysia's states and the five pillars of Islam. Its 73m-high minaret, beautiful gardens, marble pools, fountains, and vibrant tiles add to its allure.

places.name: National Mosque

reviews.text: A serene and impressive masjid that beautifully reflects Malaysia's Islamic heritage. The architecture is striking, with its unique umbrella-shaped roof and expansive courtyard creating a peaceful atmosphere. Visitors are welcomed respectfully, with robes provided for appropriate attire, allowing everyone to appreciate the space regardless of background. The mosque is well maintained and offers a calm escape from the busy city. While it's not a lengthy stop, it's definitely worth a visit for its cultural and spiritual significance. Definitely worth a visit in particular if you are visiting the museum across the road.

I was truly impressed by how clean, well organized, and beautifully maintained the National Mosque is.
Everything felt calm and peaceful, The architecture reflects the timeless beauty of Islamic mosques, with a unique modern twist. The striking blue umbrella shaped dome is unlike any other, A truly welcoming and inspiring place to visit.
üïå‚ú®

A stunning mosque in the heart of Kuala Lumpur üïå‚ú®, just a short walk from the Islamic Arts Museum - definitely worth a visit if you're in the area!

What makes this place even more special, aside from its gorgeous architecture, is the warm hospitality. Friendly ladies are on-site to welcome visitors and are happy to share insights about Islam. Whether you're Muslim or not, you'll feel genuinely welcomed.
The interior is absolutely breathtaking - the attention to detail and intricate designs are just chef's kiss üòç. It's not just a place of worship, but also a peaceful cultural experience. A must-visit if you're curious about Islamic architecture and history in Malaysia!

places.address: Jalan Perdana, Perdana Botanical Gardens, 50480 Kuala Lumpur, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

places.generalDescription: Suria KLCC, a 6-storey shopping hub that opened in 1998, is a popular destination for both locals and tourists of all ages. Situated next to the iconic PETRONAS Twin Towers, the mall offers designer boutiques and international restaurants. Visitors can explore indoor attractions like the Petrosains Discovery Center and Aquaria KLCC, or enjoy outdoor activities at the lush 50-acre KLCC Park.

places.name: Suria KLCC

reviews.text: A nice mall here which is in the towers. The areas around the mall are nice for raking photos. It's lit up well in the night. The fountain show is held in the evening. The park around also is a nice walk. All top brands are available in this mall but mostly none are on discount.

Suria KLCC is one of the most popular shopping malls in Kuala Lumpur. It is located in the heart of the city, right next to the Petronas Twin Towers.

The mall has many shops, from luxury brands to more affordable stores, so everyone can find something they like. It is clean, modern, and well-maintained.

There are lots of restaurants and cafes that serve both local and international food. There is also a large food court with cheaper choices. Suria KLCC also has fun attractions like Aquaria KLCC (an aquarium), a cinema, and the Petrosains Science Centre, which are great for families and children.

It is easy to get there, especially by LRT (light rail transit). At night, the view of the Twin Towers from the mall is very beautiful.

Overall, Suria KLCC is a great place to shop, eat, and spend time with family or friends. It is highly recommended for both tourists and locals. ‚ù§Ô∏è

Lots of high end shops and a great food hall spread over six floors. Highly recommended Lavender bakery. Sits beneath the iconic PETRONAS Twin Towers and leads into both KLCC Park and Aquaria KLCC via tunnels.

places.address: Lot No. 241, Level 2Menara, Petronas Twin Tower, Kuala Lumpur City Centre, 50088 Kuala Lumpur, Wilayah Persekutuan Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

places.generalDescription: Merdeka Square, the main square in Kuala Lumpur, holds historical significance as the site where Malaya declared independence from colonial rule in 1957. The square features a 95m flagpole marking the spot of the first Malayan flag-raising and is now home to the national day parade held annually at the end of August. The area includes the Sultan Abdul Samad Building and a large field, offering a picturesque setting for visitors to stroll and take photos.

sources.snippet: - Visit this famous landmark, a massive open field with well-manicured lawns in Malaysia popularly known as the Merdeka Square. - Witness the world‚Äôs tallest flagpoles pitched here that stands almost 95 meters high and has the Malaysian flag flying at the top. -  Click pictures of the majestic Sultan Abdul Samad building and the Royal Selangor Club that overlook the square
sources.shortName: 20 Instagrammable Places in Kuala Lumpur For The Best Shots! 2024!

sources.snippet: Are you ready to discover one of the most iconic and historically significant sites in Malaysia?. Look no further than this awe-inspiring square, surrounded by stunning colonial-era architecture that exudes a sense of grandeur and history. As you wander around, keep your keen eyes peeled for moments of magic and intrigue that you can capture in your shots.
sources.shortName: 5 Best Locations For Street Photography In KL

sources.snippet: This historical landmark is also known as Dataran Merdeka and is located in the heart of the city. Merdeka Square is surrounded by iconic buildings, including the Sultan Abdul Samad Building and the Royal Selangor Club. The square is also home to the tallest flagpole in the world, standing at 95 meters tall.
sources.shortName: 22 Gorgeous Kuala Lumpur Instagram Spots For the Best Photos

sources.snippet: The Dataran Merdeka Square (Independence Square) is a big square in Kuala Lumpur. This is where Malaysia celebrates its independence. The square is located in front of the Sultan Abdul Samad Building, which is a beautiful building.
sources.shortName: 21x The Most Instagrammable Kuala Lumpur Spots
13 Best Photo Spots in Kuala Lumpur That You Can‚Äôt Miss

places.name: Merdeka Square

reviews.text:
PARKING TIPS:

I visited Merdeka Square during the Merdeka Night Festival and it was an unforgettable experience. Parking is normally affordable in the one level basement directly under the square and you can climb the stairs up easily. During the festival, only vendors were allowed to park there, so I left my car at Rumah Tangsi next to Bank Rakyat. It was very convenient and only a short walking distance to the square on event days.

The square is well maintained with a large open field that many Malaysian families use for picnics, games with children and enjoying the outdoors. It is also a popular spot for tourists, so expect it to be more packed on weekend evenings.

The food during the event was excellent, served from food trucks with many different choices. Portions were satisfying and the variety made it enjoyable for everyone. On most weekends there are events or activities happening here, so there is often something special to try.

The atmosphere at night is lively, with bright lights, music and people creating a festive mood. Entry is free and that makes it even better. Crowds and traffic are heavier on weekends, but it adds to the city experience.

Merdeka Square is open all day and night. PARKING INFO ADDED

The best time to visit is in the evening when the surrounding heritage buildings, especially the Sultan Abdul Samad Building, are beautifully lit up.

Tip for visitors: bring a picnic mat so you can sit comfortably on the grass and enjoy the view.

Right in the heart of Kuala Lumpur, you can find a cluster of charming old buildings that immediately catch your eye with their unique architecture and beautiful, vibrant colors. Walking around this area feels like stepping back in time, as the historical design blends so gracefully with the modern city around it. It's a spot that truly showcases the cultural heritage of Kuala Lumpur and makes you appreciate how much history is preserved amidst all the skyscrapers.

This was my first visit, and I was really excited to capture some beautiful photos and videos. Unfortunately, during my trip, part of the building was undergoing renovation. While it's great to see that efforts are being made to restore and maintain these historic structures, it meant that some sections were covered or inaccessible, and I couldn't get the perfect shots I was hoping for.

Even so, I still enjoyed exploring the area and taking in the details of the architecture that was visible. I definitely plan to come back once the renovation is complete, because I can already imagine how stunning the building will look when fully restored. It's truly a must‚Äëvisit spot for anyone who loves history, photography, or simply appreciating the beauty of Kuala Lumpur.

This is one of the most historic spots in Malaysia
, it's where the country declared independence. The buildings around the square have a nice old-school vibe. It looks super pretty if you come during the day with blue skies and clouds in the background, but it can get really hot and sunny, and there's not much shade. So bring an umbrella if you're visiting in the daytime.

There's a paid basement parking nearby. Before you leave, don't forget to go to the machine near the staircase to key in your car plate number and pay, or you won't be able to drive out.

places.address: Kuala Lumpur City Centre, 50050 Kuala Lumpur, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

places.generalDescription: Batu Caves, located in Kuala Lumpur, is a must-see destination with its ancient limestone caves and Hindu temples. The 400-million-year-old mystical caves are nestled within a massive limestone cliff and have been an important religious site for Hindus. In 2018, the entire complex was renovated, including the iconic rainbow-colored staircase that has made it a popular spot for Instagram-worthy photos.

sources.snippet: Batu Caves are frequently visited by Hindu devotees who gather at this holy place to celebrate Thaipusam every year. The golden statue of Lord Murugan welcomes you before you climb 272 concrete steps up to the caves. The Kuala Lumpur city skyline (including the KL Tower and Petronas Twin Towers) can be seen from afar as you stop to snap the view.
sources.shortName: The 21 Most Instagram-Worthy Spots In Kuala Lumpur

sources.snippet: RELATED READ: If you want to read more info about this awesome place, I recommend checking out my dedicated article where I‚Äôm telling you about my experience and lots of useful info: Kuala Lumpur: A Complete Guide to the Batu Caves. Okay, I admit it: I cheated a bit by inserting this attraction here, as it‚Äôs not exactly inside the city. But it‚Äôs still one of the best things to do in Kuala Lumpur ‚Äì and a famous one, too.

The newly painted stairs of the Batu Caves can‚Äôt be missed on this list with the most Instagram worthy places in KL. 272 rainbow-colored steps, how cool is that?!. The Batu Caves is a popular spot to visit, so make sure to come during sunrise to get shots without other people.
sources.shortName: 21x The Most Instagrammable Kuala Lumpur Spots
Instagrammable spots in Kuala Lumpur

places.name: Batu Caves

reviews.text:
Had an opportunity to visit Batu Caves and golden statue of Lord Muruga. A dream come true and feeling blessed. Batu Cave is an absolutely breathtaking cultural and spiritual landmark in Malaysia. The towering golden statue of Lord Muruga is truly majestic and awe-inspiring, welcoming visitors with a powerful presence. Climbing the colorful staircase to the main cave is a rewarding experience, offering stunning views and a deep sense of peace and reverence. The temple inside the cave is serene and filled with vibrant Hindu traditions, making it a must-visit for anyone interested in culture, spirituality, or photography.

The entire area is well-maintained, with facilities and shops nearby for refreshments and souvenirs. The cave formations, combined with the religious significance, create a truly unique experience. Visiting early in the morning adds to the calm and allows for a more personal spiritual moment. A perfect place to admire natural beauty and cultural richness in one visit. Highly recommended.

A fascinating mix of adventure and spirituality! üåÑ I had such a joyful early morning workout. Highly recommend going in the morning (7:00-8:00) to avoid the heat-the atmosphere is incredibly peaceful and soothing.
Some tips for your visit: the steps are quite high and narrow, so it's best to wear loose, comfortable clothes to climb more easily. üßó‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Watch out for the cheeky monkeys-they're always around! üêí

Don't miss the nearby Ramayana Cave if you want the full experience. It's deep, mysterious, and worth exploring, while Batu Caves itself is truly majestic and awe-inspiring

The caves are made of limestone estimated to be around 400 million years old.

The site is dedicated to Lord Murugan (Murugan Swamy / Subramaniar).

The main attraction is the giant golden statue of Lord Murugan, standing 42.7 meters (140 feet) tall ‚Äì the tallest Murugan statue in the world.

1. 272 Steps

Visitors climb 272 colorful steps to reach the main Temple Cave.

2. Temple Cave (Cathedral Cave)

The biggest cave, with Hindu shrines and temples inside.

3. Dark Cave

A natural conservation site with unique animals and rock formations (requires guided tour).

4. Ramayana Cave

Depicts scenes from the Ramayana with statues and paintings.

places.address: Gombak, 68100 Batu Caves, Selangor, Malaysia

places.generalDescription: The Perdana Botanical Garden in Kuala Lumpur is a must-visit destination, known for its tropical plants, rare fruit trees, and various attractions. The Orchid Gardens cover 10,000 square meters and showcase 800 orchid varieties along with fountains and walking paths. The Hibiscus Garden is famous for Malaysia's national flower. Weekends are bustling with tourists engaging in activities, creating an enjoyable atmosphere.

sources.snippet: Tucked within the heart of the city is an Eden of tropical flowers. The Perdana Botanical Garden consists of a few famous spots, including the Hibiscus Garden, Herbarium, Sunken Garden, and more. Whether it‚Äôs a photo while strolling around the park or by the lake, this beautiful flower paradise will definitely make your Instagram ‚Äúbloom.

sources.snippet: Laman Perdana is most probably Perdana Botanical Gardens' most instagrammable spot. Completed in 2014 by GDP Architects, this canopy adopts a form that mimics its green surroundings, and is best admired on a sunny day when filtered light creates a mesmering pattern on the floor.
sources.shortName: Heartpatrick City Guides - 34 Kuala Lumpur Hidden Instagram-Worthy Hotspots That You Need To Explore Now

places.name: Perdana Botanical Garden

reviews.text: This garden is one of the best places to spend time with nature. It's clean, green, and very well organized. I loved the walking paths, and there are a lot of benches to sit and enjoy the view. The air feels fresh, and the whole environment is calm and relaxing. Great for morning walks, photography, or just to clear your mind. Everything is well-maintained, and the flowers are colorful and fresh. Perfect place for walking and relaxing. I really enjoyed my time here. Highly recommended

A very spacious garden, neatly maintained and perfect for a refreshing escape in the middle of the city. Many people come here to jog or exercise, with long tracks available for walking or running. The big lake adds to the fresh atmosphere and makes the whole place feel even more relaxing. A great spot to recharge and enjoy nature.

This park is a fantastic place to get active and recharge. This was my second visit, and I learned my lesson: ditch the office clothes and wear something light, comfortable, and ready for a good sweat! The park is huge, so even with hundreds of people jogging and walking, it never feels crowded.
I highly recommend going early in the morning. The weather is much friendlier before the sun gets too high, making your workout more enjoyable. There are tons of paths to explore, from wide-open walkways to more secluded trails where you can find a bit of solitude. I was also surprised to discover a concert hall within the park, which adds to its unique charm.
The park is beautiful and incredibly well-maintained. The people are also very disciplined, which makes for a peaceful and respectful atmosphere. Whether you're looking for an intense workout or a quiet place to unwind and clear your head after a long week, this park is a perfect spot to reconnect with nature and recharge.

places.address: Jalan Kebun Bunga, Perdana Botanical Gardens, 55100 Kuala Lumpur, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

places.generalDescription: KLCC Park is a sprawling 50-acre urban oasis nestled around the iconic Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur. The park features a manmade lake called Lake Symphony, where visitors can enjoy choreographed fountain displays and water shows. With over 1900 trees, including various species of palms and indigenous flora, the park was carefully designed to attract local and migratory birds while promoting biodiversity. Visitors can also explore walking paths, sculptures, a playground for kids, and even a wading pool.

sources.snippet: Now that I told you about the Petronas Twin Towers, I have to mention KLCC Park right away. This green landscaped park is located right behind the towers and it‚Äôs a great place to relax, unwind and get a great view of the towers from afar. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, the park is quite large ‚Äì it has over 20 hectares, so you‚Äôll have plenty of space to find a good spot for you.

This green oasis is located in the heart of the city and offers a stunning backdrop for your snaps. One of the most popular spots in KLCC Park is the man-made Lake Symphony, which features a stunning water fountain show set to music in the evening. This is a great spot to capture some unique and colorful shots of the city skyline and the fountain show.
sources.shortName: 22 Gorgeous Kuala Lumpur Instagram Spots For the Best Photos

sources.snippet: Over two decades since their completion, the Petronas Twin Towers continue to be the most recognisable landmark of the city. While we are never short of a cool vantage point of the gleaming structures, the adjoining park offers one of the best spots in town to admire the towers, given its close promixity and varied installations.
sources.shortName: Heartpatrick City Guides - 34 Kuala Lumpur Hidden Instagram-Worthy Hotspots That You Need To Explore Now

sources.snippet: To make Kuala Lumpur a picturesque city and for tourists to bring back fond memories of their visit, the City Hall has located six new photo spots at the KLCC Park. These spots provide a better photo opportunity of the Petronas Twin Towers.

sources.snippet: One of the best photo spots to capture KLCC will be at the KLCC Park Garden. A free entry park for all visitors and it is right next to KLCC. So you still have access to air-conditioning, toilets and food options easily.

sources.snippet: Another great way to capture the wonderful Petronas Towers is to visit KLCC Park. From this beautiful park you will have a lot of space to try out different angles and perspectives to get your favorite one!

places.name: KLCC Park

reviews.text:
A perfect spot to relax and unwind, especially with kids! There's a nice jogging track, a spacious park, a playground, and even a water play area where kids can splash around and cool off.

Super recommended if you're looking for a quick escape after shopping nearby or even just a short healing break after work. The atmosphere is refreshing, the views are amazing, and it's definitely family-friendly. Great for light exercise, playtime, or just enjoying some peace in the city.
really nice park. great to walk around or sit down and enjoy time. good views and many things to eat just outside the park. there is also a small water fall area where kids can play in the water

One of the most beautiful parks I've been to!! It was so relaxing and the trees are such a joy to see, they provide so much air and freshness, wherever you look you will see something beautiful, the playground, the towers, the buildings, the pool the little bridge! We took so many pictures, and all of them turned great. A walk that was absolutely amazing.

places.generalDescription: Sultan Abdul Samad Jamek Mosque, built in the early 1900s, is one of the oldest mosques in Malaysia. It boasts a Moorish architectural style and sits at the confluence of the Klang and Gombak rivers, offering stunning views. Once serving as the main mosque in Kuala Lumpur, it has a rich history with famous preachers and religious leaders having attended.

sources.snippet: One of the best photo spots in Kuala Lumpur is the Jamek Mosque (Masjid Jamek in Malaysia). This mosque lies right in the city‚Äôs heart, not far from the lively Central Market and Chinatown. It is one of the oldest and most important mosques in Kuala Lumpur and stands near the confluence of the Klang and Gombak rivers.
sources.shortName: 11 Most Instagrammable Places in KL

sources.snippet: Masjid Jamek Sultan Abdul Samad is one of the oldest and most beautiful mosques in Kuala Lumpur, and it is also a great Instagrammable place in KL. You need to be dressed appropriately to be able to enter the mosque. But you can borrow a robe at the mosque for free as well.
sources.shortName: 10 Top Instagrammable Places in KL

places.name: Sultan Abdul Samad Jamek Mosque

reviews.text: A beautiful mosque. In night it's even more beautiful with the lighting and smoke effects in river. There is a nice walkway in the back where you can go for an evening walk and get some great pictures. To enter in the mosque basic dress code is required for a religious place and females need to cover their head.

One other oldest Mosque in KL.
Just next to Majid Jamek MRT/LRT station. Or 5 minutes walk from Pasar Seni.
Beware of dress code and visiting hours for non Muslim visitors.
No plan to enter. It's a beautiful Mosque beside the River of Life. Blue light is on along the river after evening. Probably having smoke effect at night. More attractive.

Serene place to pray. However, it feels a bit of a hassle that I need to cross an open area after taking ablution. Aside from that, a great mosque with an interesting history. I love the comic infographic at the front of the mosque!

places.generalDescription: The Islamic Arts Museum Malaysia, located in Kuala Lumpur, is a contemporary museum that celebrates the official religion of Malaysia. It is the largest museum of its kind in Southeast Asia and offers spacious galleries showcasing artifacts and examples of Muslim patterns in various forms such as print, jewelry, armor, coins, ceramics, and architecture.

sources.snippet: If you‚Äôre looking for an Instagram-worthy spot in Kuala Lumpur, the Islamic Arts Museum Malaysia (IAMM) is definitely worth a visit. The museum houses a vast collection of Islamic arts and artifacts, beautifully curated in its 12 permanent galleries. Located in the heart of Kuala Lumpur, the IAMM serves as an ambassador of Islamic Arts in Southeast Asia.
sources.shortName: 22 Gorgeous Kuala Lumpur Instagram Spots For the Best Photos

places.name: Islamic Arts Museum Malaysia

reviews.text:
Where culture and religion beautifully intertwine - the Islamic Arts Museum in Kuala Lumpur is truly a gem! If you're into history, art, or just love soaking up new cultures, this place is a must-visit.
The museum itself is a work of art - the domes inside are absolutely mesmerizing ‚ú®. I found myself just standing there, eyes glued to the ceiling, taking it all in. Every exhibit tells a story, and reading about the rich history behind each piece was both fascinating and inspiring.

Don't skip the souvenir shop on your way out! From elegant silk items to unique postcards, beautiful stationery, and dazzling jewelry - there's something for every kind of collector or gift hunter.

Definitely a highlight for anyone wanting to explore the artistic and spiritual heritage of the Islamic world, right in the heart of KL! üá≤üáæ

The museum is welcoming to all, with a peaceful ambiance and air-conditioned comfort, perfect for a relaxing visit. The Moza Restaurant serves delicious Middle Eastern cuisine, and the gift shop is a treasure trove of unique crafts. Admission is reasonable at RM20, and the location near the National Mosque and Perdana Botanical Gardens makes it a must-visit. I spent about 1.5 hours here and left inspired by the artistry and history. Highly recommend for anyone interested in culture, history, or simply a beautiful museum experience.

The displays are well-organized across 12 galleries, making it easy to explore the rich heritage of the Islamic world, with highlights from Malaysia, China, India, and beyond.

One of the highlights for me at the Islamic Arts Museum KL was the collection of miniature mosque models.
I was amazed by how beautifully crafted and detailed they were.
What made it even more special was the diverse selection of mosques from all around the world, each representing unique architectural styles and cultural significance.

places.address: Jalan Lembah, Perdana Botanical Gardens, 50480 Kuala Lumpur, Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

places.generalDescription: Menara Kuala Lumpur, one of the tallest freestanding towers globally and the highest in Southeast Asia, stands majestically at 421 meters. This iconic landmark is not just a communications hub but also a fantastic viewpoint offering breathtaking panoramic views of Kuala Lumpur. Visitors can indulge in a unique dining experience at its revolving restaurant, which provides a stunning 360-degree perspective of the city as they savor their meals.

reviews.text: ABSOLUTELY worth the visit, very beautiful observation deck. This was my second time here and previously i went during the day, however i would recommended heading up before sunset , seeing sunset and then heading down after dark. It's absolutely beautiful to see the city in both daytime and nighttime. It is worth noting too that after sunset the observation deck did get a lot quieter. As someone who isn't fond of lifts it is over within a few minutes and staff are constantly monitoring them.

KL Tower offers a peaceful escape high above the city with some truly stunning panoramic views of Kuala Lumpur. Whether you visit during the day or around sunset, the cityscape looks beautiful from the observation deck. The tower itself is well-maintained and organized, and the experience feels calm and enjoyable. There are a few small attractions around the base as well, making it a pleasant spot to explore. Overall, a quiet yet memorable place to take in the beauty of KL from above. Definitely worth a visit if you're in the city and want a relaxed experience with a great view.

KL Tower is one of the best spots to experience breathtaking 360¬∞ views of Kuala Lumpur. The observation deck and Sky Deck offer stunning sights, especially at sunset or night. The glass sky box is a thrilling highlight! The tower is well-maintained, and staff are friendly and helpful. Surrounded by nature and cultural attractions, it's a perfect mix of city views and local charm. A must-visit landmark for every traveler to Malaysia.

places.name: Sky Deck KL Tower

reviews.text:
The Sky Deck KL Tower is a must-visit attraction in Kuala Lumpur, offering breathtaking 360-degree views of the city from 300+ meters high.

Best time to visit is during sunset and at night when the city lights twinkle. You can see both the day look & night look of KL from here.

Pros:
- Breathtaking views_: The Sky Deck provides unobstructed views of the city, making it perfect for photography
- Unique experience_: The Sky Box, a glass-floored box protruding from the Sky Deck, offers an exhilarating experience
- Convenient_: Tickets can be purchased easily, and visitors can take a taxi to the tower, which is located on a steep hill

Cons:
- Expensive: Tickets are priced at 99MYR each, which some visitors find steep .
- Queues: Expect long queues, especially during peak season, but some visitors recommend visiting during off-peak hours or booking in advance to avoid the crowds
- Avoid visit during Rain, as they will close the deck during rain, & you cannot extend or refund your tickets.

Tips:
- Book tickets in advance to avoid queues and get discounts
- Visit during off-peak hours or early in the morning to avoid crowds
- Don't miss the Sky Box experience, but be prepared for a wait

Overall, the Sky Deck KL Tower is a fantastic spot to take in the city views and enjoy a unique experience.

Warning: Be cautious of the photographer on the rooftop!
We paid the highest price to access the building and take photos at the top. Once we reached the rooftop, we were charged an additional $10 to access the glass platform for photos. Unfortunately, the photographer took too long and wasted most of our time. When our session ended, we were shocked to be asked for an extra $70 just to receive the photos!
This is a clear scam targeting visitors. Sadly, we left without our photos. A very disappointing and frustrating experience. I do not recommend this service unless they change their approach and become more transparent with pricing.

Very pathetic. The tower is  nice with spectacular views but the ticketing system is so bad. Very mean people handling all this. Charged the maximum of 140 Malaysian Ringit but not allowed to go to observation deck.
These fools asked fo another 10 Ringit for glass deck on the top.
They didn't mention while purchasing tickets on the ground but after reaching the top.
How mean I don't word for this poor management.
Don't commit mistakes of getting your photos shot on the deck.Youll committed biggest mistake.

The beautiful bridge‚Äôs architecture is inspired by the sireh junjung (betel nut leaf arrangement) concept, which is an integral part of a Malay wedding. reviews.text: I recently visited Pintasan Saloma, and it was a truly memorable experience. The place was quite crowded, especially during the evening, but that only added to its lively and energetic vibe. The bridge itself is beautifully designed, with a stunning and modern architectural style that lights up gorgeously at night. It's a great spot for photos, offering amazing views of the Kuala Lumpur skyline, especially the iconic Petronas Towers. Despite the crowd, the atmosphere was enjoyable, and the entire area felt safe and clean. It's definitely a must-visit landmark for anyone exploring the heart of Kuala Lumpur. I loved it!

Saloma Link Bridge at night is absolutely stunning. The bridge lights up in shifting colors in my photo you can see four different shades glowing through the structure, with the Petronas Twin Towers perfectly framed in the background. A beautiful blend of modern architecture and vibrant city energy.

If you're visiting KL, this spot is a must see at night. Great for a walk, photos or just soaking in the view!

A bridge with beautiful architecture. Very beautifully lit at night, in changing colors. From the platform at the end towards Kampung Baru you have a beautiful view. Very crowded, lots of people taking pictures.

While it serves as a place of worship for the local Tamil community, visitors can explore the grounds to admire its architecture and immerse themselves in its spiritual ambiance.

places.name: Sri Maha Mariamman Temple

reviews.text:
This Hindu temple is one of the most vibrant and visually stunning places I've ever visited. The moment you stand in front of the entrance, you're struck by the colorful and detailed tower gate (gopuram) that rises high above the street. Covered in hundreds of intricately carved and painted deities, the facade is a masterpiece of South Indian Dravidian architecture.

As you step inside, the atmosphere changes instantly-peaceful, spiritual, and filled with the scent of incense. The interior is equally beautiful, with shrines dedicated to various Hindu deities, including Lord Ganesha, Lord Shiva, and Goddess Durga. Every statue is decorated with fresh flowers and silk garments, and the attention to detail is absolutely incredible.

What I found especially touching was how the space is open to both worshippers and curious visitors. People were taking photos respectfully, while others offered prayers or lit incense. It felt like a sacred place that also welcomed cultural exchange.

If you're in Kuala Lumpur, this temple is a must-visit-not only for its visual beauty, but for the sense of serenity and cultural richness it offers. It's free to enter, but please dress modestly and be respectful of the rituals taking place. I truly appreciated the hospitality and the opportunity to learn more about Hindu culture through this beautiful site.

Sri Maha Mariamman Temple is one of the oldest Hindu landmarks in Kuala Lumpur, known for its colorful and intricate facade. A great place for photography and experiencing the city's cultural diversity. My visit was solely for photography, with no religious involvement.üõïüáÆüá∂üá≤üáæ

One of KL's most stunning and culturally rich landmarks! Built in the 1870s, this is the oldest Hindu temple in the city, and it still plays an important role in the local Tamil community's religious life.

The temple's highlight is its incredibly detailed gopuram (tower), covered in hundreds of brightly coloured deities and mythological figures - it's impossible to walk past without stopping to look up. Inside, the temple is just as beautiful, with richly painted ceilings, polished floors, and sacred shrines surrounded by fresh flowers and oil lamps.

It's a peaceful space with a real sense of devotion and tradition. You might even catch a short prayer ceremony while visiting. Don't forget to remove your shoes at the entrance and dress respectfully. A great place to pause, learn, and appreciate one of KL's key religious sites right near the hustle and bustle of Chinatown.

places.generalDescription: Thean Hou Temple, also known as the Temple of the Goddess of Heaven, is a magnificent six-tiered Buddhist temple that opened in 1989. Located on a hill overlooking lush surroundings, it can be reached from KL Sentral Station by foot or taxi. This Chinese-style temple beautifully combines contemporary and traditional elements of Buddhism, Taoism, and Confucianism.

sources.snippet: This six-tiered Buddhist temple is known as the Temple of the Goddess of Heaven. Buddhist worshippers also come to the shrine pray to the Goddess of Mercy and celebrate Chinese festivals including Wesak Day and Mooncake Festival. The temple comprises both contemporary and traditional architectural designs of Buddhism, Taoism and Confucianism.

It is sitting on a hill overviewing the leafy surroundings and is reachable from KL Sentral Station via foot (30 min) or taxi (10 min). Uniquely combining both contemporary and traditional elements of Buddhism, Taoism, and Confucianism, this temple is worth the feed, inner peace and a sense of going back in time to discover it‚Äôs beauty carved and done by men before technology took over to create!

sources.snippet: Thean Hou Temple is also known as the Temple of the Goddess of Heaven and it‚Äôs famous for being one of the oldest Chinese temples not only in Malaysia, but in this entire part of the world as well!. It‚Äôs massive and its six tier architecture is simply stunning: a red roof, hundreds of hanging Chinese lanterns and intricate carvings painted in endless colours. If you only visit one temple in KL, Thean Hou should be it; it is surely high on my list of beautiful tourist attractions in Kuala Lumpur for some incredible photos!

Considered by many to be the most beautiful Chinese Buddhist temple in Kuala Lumpur, Thean Hou Temple is dedicated to Shui Wei Sheng Niang and Tian Hou, an ancient Hainanese sea goddess, along with Guan Yin, the goddess of mercy. This lavish temple is marked by intricate carvings, detailed artworks and colorful, sloping roofs in a mix of traditional Taoist, Confucius and Buddhist temple styles. Thean Hou Temple is particular spectacular during Chinese cultural festivals like the Lunar New Year and Mid-Autumn Festival.

sources.snippet: If you have visited Buddhist temples in the past, you will know that no holds are barred when it comes to extravagance.In like fashion, Thean Hou Temple, located Southwest of the city, is certainly no exception. The hilltop position away from the hustle and bustle provides peace and serenity unlike anywhere else in the city.Although, it is the vibrant colours and creative angles which earn Thean Hou its title as one of the best Instagram spots in Kuala Lumpur. TIP ‚Äì We recommend visiting early to avoid the crowds.

places.name: Thean Hou Temple

reviews.text:
The temple is incredible!!! definitely worth a visit, especially on the weekend. It's spotless, welcoming to tourists, and perfect for snapping Instagram-worthy shots. Getting there is easiest with Grab, but if you don't mind a short walk, the train is also an option. I went on a Wednesday, and it was pretty quiet, which made the atmosphere feel extra calm and peaceful.

When it comes to the dress code, modesty is important. Women should avoid revealing clothes, but a light scarf works great if you want to cover up quickly. Long skirts or dresses are ideal, while men are fine wearing shorts.

One of the highlights was catching the sunset from the temple. I only got to see it for a brief moment, but it was absolutely magical. Other than that, the whole environment feels serene, peaceful, and just really chill-a perfect place to sit back, soak it all in, and enjoy the calm.

So beautiful temple! We came in the morning to see less people and have possibility to enjoy the atmosphere but still saw a lot of people. We were lucky to see many weddings! So many beautiful couples came there to be married and take beautiful pictures and videos with pro photographers.

There is small pond near the entrance with rich fishes (people leave coins there) and figures of Chinese horoscope.

To visit the temple you need to go upstairs. Inside your should leave your shoes near the entrance.

I really like this place even as a traveller, beautifully decorated, with many details, don't miss opportunity to walk inside and outside. There are many amazing zones for photographs

Inside you can get an answer on your questions using special number boards. Check the video to see see what you should do :)

There is a dress code inside (check one of the pictures)

Very beautiful and interesting. Here you can pray and ask for fortune. Beautiful architecture and hung with many lanterns. I saw families taking wedding photos here too. Should go early it will be less crowded after 9:30 there will be many groups of people coming.

places.generalDescription: The LINC KL is a trendy retail center located in the heart of Kuala Lumpur, just a short walk from the iconic Petronas Twin Towers. Unlike other bustling malls in the city, The LINC stands out with its industrial-chic design that seamlessly incorporates old trees within its compound. This unique approach to construction has created a visually stunning environment that blends harmoniously with nature. The mall features an array of shops and eateries, making it a great place for shopping and dining.

sources.snippet: The LINC KL is a colourful new hipster mall that combines retail and greenery. Located on Jalan Tun Razak, there are plenty of photo opportunities as well as art displays. places.generalDescription: BookXcess RexKL is a unique cultural and creative hub located in downtown Kuala Lumpur, repurposed from an old cinema. Teaming up with BookXcess, known for their affordable books and captivating store designs, the space offers a haven for book enthusiasts and social media influencers alike. Inspired by Seoul's Starfield Library, the new tunnel concept bookstore has become an Instagram sensation.

reviews.text:
It was interesting not only for the variety of books, but also as a space. It was fun just to be there.
Tourists are taking pictures, enjoying the caf√©, and it is a place where you can settle down and enjoy yourself for a while, not only with books.

It is also a good place to walk around after visiting Central Market or Chinatown.

It's fun to be there with a few quirks

2. Most people there are there to take pictures (I am guilty too) only. Visitors are more interested in the environment than the books. üòÇ
3. It's like a maze if you like that "maze" adventure without paying an entrance fee.
4. I wished they have more board games as the selection were pretty limited.
5. If you like am airy feeling of a bookstore then this may not be the place but hey, each to their own liking.  üòä

Located on the top floor of the old Rex cinema, this BookXcess outlet is a must visit for anyone wanting a little adventure in a very unique place. It's unique layout, arrangements and display of products sold makes this an amazing space to be in and can be for many hours. It is also a beautiful spot for a variety of photography.

I love the interactivity this space has for any visitor that I felt like I was warped into a different time and space. Being surrounded by such earthy elements of wood and paper along with the concrete & steel bones of the old Rex cinema creates such a beautiful atmosphere. The layout creates a maze that is geared towards discovery.

I also love the breadth of products available beyond books like journals, postcards, pins, stationery, bookmarks and many more. I highly recommend this place for anyone who would love a little adventure and interaction.

places.generalDescription: Petaling Street Market, also known as Kuala Lumpur's Chinatown, is a vibrant shopping district where vendors haggle over a variety of goods, from clothing to food. The area offers a glimpse into the city's culture and history, with imitation goods and delicious street snacks making it a paradise for bargain hunters. Visitors can explore Kwai Chai Hong, an alley filled with interactive street art pieces and vibrant murals.

sources.snippet: Petaling Street, also known as Chinatown, is one of the best street photography locations in Kuala Lumpur. The area is full of lively market scenes, bright colors, and a mix of old and new buildings. As you walk through the narrow streets, you‚Äôll see vendors selling everything from traditional Chinese herbs to fashionable clothes.
sources.shortName: Top Street Photography Locations In Kuala Lumpur

places.name: Petaling Street Market

reviews.text:
Busy street where you can find best souvenir to take back home.
A variety of street food, drinks, electronic items, apparels and also don't miss Candy and Chocolates to buy from shop across the street. While you are shopping don't miss to stop to bargain so you can get the best deal. Overall a good place to spend some time and shop, shop, shop.. üòâ

I visited Petaling Street, and it was quite an experience! The market is larger than I expected, bustling with energy, shops, and a wide variety of goods ranging from clothes and accessories to souvenirs and local street food.

Prices are generally not expensive, but be prepared to negotiate-bargaining is absolutely essential here. One important tip: never reveal your offer price first. It's always better to let the vendors quote their lowest price before you start negotiating. With a bit of patience and good negotiation skills, you can score some great deals.

That said, the area could use some improvement in terms of cleanliness and overall hygiene. While the atmosphere is vibrant and lively, a bit more attention to sanitation would really enhance the visitor experience.

Overall, it's a fun and colorful place to explore, especially if you enjoy street shopping and local culture. Just go in with the right mindset and be ready to haggle!

This places become more alive after evening time. This market has mainly "AAA" branded items and even branded watches and all. Frankly speaking, not very ideal if you wanna do souvenir shopping, most of the sellers will try to hustle you to buy something, especially if you show a slight bit of interest. I would avoid asking how much it is unless youre really interested in it.

places.generalDescription: Sin Sze Si Ya Temple, established in 1864, is a Chinese Taoist temple located in the Chinatown area of Kuala Lumpur. It is the oldest Chinese temple in the city and was built under the direction of Kapitan Yap Ah Loy. The temple is dedicated to Sin Sze Ya and Si Sze Ya, two deities believed to have played a role in Yap's rise to Kapitan status.

sources.snippet: I may have lost count of the number of chinese temple that I have visited here in Kuala Lumpur, but there is nothing quite like Sin Sze Si Ya Temple. Befitting of its title as the oldest Taoist temple in the city, it was built by Yap Ah Loy in 1883, and has since stood at its location till this day. The surreal atmosphere of the temple is best appreciated on a sunny afternoon, where shafts of light streaming down from its age-old windows in the courtyard come to life against the rising incense smoke from the altars below.
sources.shortName: Heartpatrick City Guides - 34 Kuala Lumpur Hidden Instagram-Worthy Hotspots That You Need To Explore Now

places.name: Sin Sze Si Ya Temple

reviews.text:
Sin Sze Si Ya Temple ‚Äì Kuala Lumpur
Absolutely worth a visit! This is the oldest Taoist temple in Kuala Lumpur, founded in 1864 by Yap Ah Loy, one of the city's early Chinese Kapitans. Tucked down a narrow alley off Jalan Tun H S Lee, the temple is a peaceful, atmospheric escape from the busy streets outside.

Inside, it's a sensory experience - thick incense, glowing red lanterns, and centuries-old wooden carvings. Every corner is filled with colour and symbolism, from the altar to the fortune-telling sticks and prayer offerings. You'll also find vibrant red and gold detailing, traditional tiled floors, and beautiful antique decorations that reflect a strong mix of Chinese-Malay heritage.

Whether you're stopping in to soak up the atmosphere, take photos, or quietly reflect, this temple offers a unique glimpse into KL's early Chinese community and spiritual traditions. Don't miss the outdoor incense urns and side altars - and look out for the pineapple and fruit offerings!

Another old chinese temple that has different god statue and meaningful chinese temple culture. With loadsa old building structure. If you have extra time can always come over these temple just for a soothing moment or a prayer to calm down the day

A Chinese temple tucked away nearby Chinatown (Petaling Street), very rich in local Malaysian culture. Plenty of services for prayers.

There's a free chop here for tourists to have as a free souvenir.

Counter service is suitable for locals and tourists as he's Indian and speaks English well.

places.generalDescription: Laman Perdana, situated in Heritage Park, was originally a recreational park but has been transformed into a stunning botanical garden featuring a wide variety of plant species from Africa such as Moringas and Adansonias. The garden also includes a picturesque lake filled with fish and turtles at its center. Visitors can enjoy the serene ambiance while exploring the lush greenery and taking advantage of amenities like picnic areas and jogging circuits. Additionally, there are attractions like butterfly parks and deer viewing areas within the botanical garden.

sources.snippet: Laman Perdana is most probably Perdana Botanical Gardens' most instagrammable spot. Completed in 2014 by GDP Architects, this canopy adopts a form that mimics its green surroundings, and is best admired on a sunny day when filtered light creates a mesmering pattern on the floor.
sources.shortName: Heartpatrick City Guides - 34 Kuala Lumpur Hidden Instagram-Worthy Hotspots That You Need To Explore Now

places.name: Laman Perdana

reviews.text: Nice place to spend some time enjoying the many attractions for free. Must see while you are here is the Sunken Garden, an instagrammers delight. There is plenty of seating around it in the shade, while you wait for the many people photographing to disperse. It has a lot of delightful colour.

Laman Perdana in Kuala Lumpur is a charming spot within the Perdana Botanical Garden. Entry was free, and the available restrooms were clean and well-maintained. Everything felt very peaceful, the perfect place for a relaxing walk or to unwind surrounded by nature right in the heart of the city.

The large garden in KUL. You can walk around and relax with nature in the morning or evening to prevent the hot weather. Please save the Map from the map board for reference in case you don't lose the way.

places.generalDescription: Merchant's Lane is a trendy cafe with a funky design that serves light meals from Malaysia and beyond. Housed in a heritage shop-house, the space has undergone a remarkable transformation from an 1980s brothel to a hip cafe. The interior exudes charm with its old school signboard, rattan furniture, wooden floors, vintage trinkets, floral paintings, and weathered walls. It offers a respite from the hustle and bustle of Chinatown.

sources.snippet: This former brothel in Petaling Street has been turned into one of the most Instagram-worthy cafes in KL, decorated with oriental interiors and hints of tropical plants. I've been to petaling street numerous times but never knew this hidden cafe through a narrow door beside a stationary shop ü§£ , was surprised when my friend told me about it. Food portion is enormous, a little high on the pricing, but one dish fits two easily. Go for the Ramly patty fried wonton, first time tasting, and loving it. Interior design with wood and rattan, Malaysian traditional style. Service can be better with an added smiles from the waiters. Worth a visit!

I visited the popular caf√© Merchant's Lane in Chinatown, Kuala Lumpur. The entrance is quite hidden, but once you step inside, you're welcomed into a completely different world - a retro and stylish interior with a rustic charm. The slightly worn walls and wooden furniture create a warm, cozy atmosphere that makes you want to stay for hours.

The menu offers a creative mix of Asian and Western fusion dishes, all served in generous portions. The seafood pasta, loaded with prawns and clams, was especially delicious - creamy yet with a nice spicy kick that kept me coming back for more. The cheesy meatball gratin and crispy hot fries on the side were also very satisfying.

Drinks are just as unique. I ordered a chocolate frappe that came with a whole donut on top - not only Instagram-worthy, but also rich and indulgent in flavor, almost like a dessert on its own.

Prices are not the cheapest, as it's a popular tourist spot, but considering the ambiance and quality of food, it's definitely worth it. It's the perfect place to take a break while exploring Chinatown, and I recommend ordering a few dishes to share with friends. A must-visit caf√© when you're in Kuala Lumpur!

places.generalDescription: Kwai Chai Hong, located in Kuala Lumpur, has quickly gained popularity as a must-visit destination for photography enthusiasts. This charming heritage lane is adorned with trendy cafes, hip bars, and vibrant street art. The permanent murals and regular pop-up art installations have become a local favorite. Visitors can immerse themselves in the artwork, which includes interactive elements such as old wooden benches integrated into the murals.

sources.snippet: Kwai Chai Hong is a recently restored section of Kuala Lumpur's historic Chinatown, featuring nearly a dozen old shophouses along Jelang Petaling, many of them dating back to the early 1900s. Kwai Chai Hong refers specifically to the newly renovated alleyway between these shopfronts, and is also known as Lorong Panggung, meaning 'Ghost Alley'. In addition to heritage shopfront and historic charms of the area, newer additions to Kwai Chai Hong are the six colorful murals depicting the daily lives of early Chinese settlers.
sources.shortName: Instagram-Worthy Photo Spots in Kuala Lumpur

sources.snippet: Project Kwai Chai Hong was launched in 2019, and has revived the neglected Chinatown alleys and transformed the heritage shop lots into one of the most Instagrammable spots in Kuala Lumpur. The heritage buildings and murals by local artists are designed to reflect the early Chinese settlers who lived there during the 1960s. You can read more about Kwai Chai Hong here.
sources.shortName: Top 16 Insta-Worthy Places Around The Klang Valley To Visit For Your Next OOTD Photoshoot

sources.snippet: Or well, that was the case when we visited in 2019, just after this street got renovated. Once a dirty alley (Kwai Chai Hong means ‚ÄòLittle Demon Alley‚Äô), now an alley full of street art, restaurants, and one of our favorite Instagrammable places in KL. It‚Äôs a lovely place to visit, so we can imagine Kwai Chai Hong will get more popular every day.

sources.snippet: Kwai Chai Hong Alley breathes life into the history of Kuala Lumpur's Chinatown with its nostalgic murals and art installations. This vintage area has been transformed into a cultural hub that attracts those looking to dive into the city's heritage. üì∏ Must-Have Shot: Pose next to one of the many vibrant murals for a colorful and artistic photo.

places.name: Kwai Chai Hong

reviews.text: I wish I had more time here, as an art lover, it was such an amazing experience. You need at least a few hours to soak in all the corners and streets. Yes it's photo worthy but if you only go for the photos you'll miss out on the art and nuance of the locals ü•π

What a fantastic experience exploring Kwai Chai Hong! This small historical street in KL is impeccably maintained and restored, making it a dream for photographers. We were thrilled to find it wasn't too busy, giving us the space to capture some truly stunning pictures amidst the fun and beautiful wall art. It's clear the effort made to preserve the authentic buildings and keep this part of KL true to its roots has paid off beautifully.
